captions.text:
- I think what hurts the
most is when you're young,
and someone makes fun of the way you look.
Because you can't control that.
- I've gotten shoved into lockers.
- I was bullied by a small group of boys,
like about three boys.
- My friends always said I was kind of
easy to make fun of, but it felt like it
always came from a place of love, I hope.
- When I was a little kid I was
a little chunkier than everybody else
and all the other girls,
so people noticed that I was different
and they'd like to touch my stomach
or point it out.

Today, I think I would
say, in response to that,

I think you meant, can
I touch your six-pack.

- A guy once told me that
I would be much hotter
if I had a bigger butt.
So my response to that guy would be,

my butt does not need your
approval to be fantastic.
- I was a skinny kid, but I
didn't really have a flat stomach.

I had a little extra baby
fat that kinda hung around.
So they always told me that it
looked like I had a little kangaroo pouch.

And to this day they
still will mention it.
- When I was growing up kids would tell me

that I was adopted,
because it's impossible
for a brown girl to have a white mom.
Well, my dad is from India,
so white plus brown
is a lighter shade of brown.

Did you even listen during
middle school science?
'Cause that's not how genetics work.

- The mean comment I remember
hearing about my body
was that I had no butt.
I think many African American communities,

having a big butt is very,
like, it's looked up upon.

But it was really like
that one comment one time
that got me to realize, like, oh my God,
something's wrong with my body.

To the person who made that
comment I would say that,
maybe I'm not your cup of tea,
but my body is fine the way it is.

- It was about two to
three different bullies,
and they just would all say I was ugly.

One of them specifically,
whenever he saw me in the hallway,
he would run the opposite direction,
and just make like a huge scene about it.

People do that out of
fear, they do it to fit in.

- So in fifth grade, a
boy who was in my class
told me that I had fat thighs.
My response to him now would be that
my thighs were not fat, they were strong.

Now I actually like think
I have really great thighs.
- The thing that I got teased most for was
my mustache and my general body hair.
And my name is Fazeelat.
Fuzzy was a really easy nickname.
It's because of people like you
who picked on me and hurt me,
that I became as strong as I am today.
- I feel bad for people that
feel a need to bully other kids,

'cause it's probably just
coming from a really dark place.
- So instead of trying to fix themselves,
they're just trying to make you feel bad

about yourself and say
mean things about you.

- Work on being comfortable
with your own body,
and be around people that love you.

- Don't let their words affect
how you feel about yourself.

- They're probably jealous
of how pretty your skin is.

title: Women Respond To Their Childhood Bullies

met them again a few weeks ago this was response 'hello you little bitches,

comments.author: DancingPotatoe16

comments.text:
I am a very fair skinned girl, and I'm also anemic so it makes me even more 
pale. I'm bulled alot and made fun of cause of how pale I am. I'm called a 
vampire, snow white, whitey, and lots more. People tell me I should get out 
more in the sun, but I can't tan at all I only burn. What makes it worse is 
that my skin is sensitive so I'm allergic to sun screen badly allergic. My 
skin is a time limit when I'm out open in the sun so I'm talking 25 to 30 
minutes of pool time after that I was dragged out of the pool by my parents 
so I wouldn't burn. One time in middle school a girl told me that I should 
dye my hair a lighter color of brown so I wouldn't look so pale, her 
friends thought she was sooo funny. And I told her that maybe you should 
lighten up on the spray tan you look like an orange, and I walked away. She 
and her friends where speechless XD lol. I realized when I was older that 
my skin is beautiful just the way it is I'm a true rarity. When I look in 
the mirror I don't see a white vampire I see a flawless angel. ﻿

comments.author: thatonevegangirl

comments.text:
In connection to the woman who has a white mom and an Indian father: 
genetics actually work in very interesting ways. The fact that darker 
colors carry dominant alleles does explain why most children of such a 
racial mix usually bear non-white traits, but it actually can work the 
other way as well. Mutation of genes is always possible, therefore you can 
have a mixed race kid who looks completely white because in that case the 
genes carrying dominant alleles sort of "break" and behave like recessive 
ones, which are responsible for lighter colors such as blonde hair, fair 
skin, blue eyes, etc. So basically a completely white child born in a mixed 
race relationship is possible, only very, very, very rare. Like, extremely 
rare. It's an interesting topic really.﻿

comments.author: lanaitgirl

comments.text:
To be honest I sort of feel the only way to respond to verbal bullying by 
taking what they say in any way but how they mean it, without being overtly 
rude. Turn them into a joke. Some dickhead keeps running away from you? 
Start chasing them, tell them they're soooooo sexy you just can't keep 
away. You don't have a fashionably large ass? The very last thing you want 
to do is treat them as if their opinion matters in any way. Once a person 
is cruel to you, you should remind yourself that they are clearly 
miserable, unreasonable people and write them off.
I'd ask them if they realised that they feel the need to point out other 
people's faults because they hate themselves so damn much.
Bullying says everything about the bully and nothing about the victim.﻿

comments.author: Kenni Ling

comments.text:
i was bullied because I was always tall and never that cute sweet girl like 
the most girls. Luckily i had my friends so it actually didn't bother me. 
And one day I accidently hit a boy who was teasing me a bit (he was a 
classmate and normally okay) and some of the class saw that. I never told 
anyone about it but it was rumored in the whole school. That helped me with 
bullies. Years later one boy tried to tease me in the drawing class, but 
when I stood up to pick some water for painting, he stood up as well and 
run some steps. He thought I stood up because of him and scared. At that 
moment I was confused: Why he tried to bully me when he's afraid of me? Now 
I like the story and I like to share it. 

For all the bully victims stand up, you don't have to hit someone like I 
did. My friend was bullied, too (because she was fat and foreign), and she 
told me once she didn't care at all, because she had friends. So don't care 
about bullies, don't give them any power over you. Looking for something 
you like and do it and look for friends who like you how you are. You're 
lucky to be born these days, thanks internet you can find easier some who 
went through the same (look at all these comments on this video). You're 
not alone and you're great. There is a place for you in the world. And like 
the one woman wrote it makes you stronger. I know it's hard but I believe 
everyone can go through the hell of being bullied by focus one the good 
things in your life. And the best thing in your life is you. There will be 
always bad things but you can make good things. Like you see in my story, 
in the end the bully is more scared than you (when you don't give him any 
power).﻿

K Gates

comments.text:
When I was in kindergarten my friend Megan suddenly stopped talking to me. 
She avoided me, and apparently this was sudden because our friend Natalie 
was confused as to why she wasn't talking to me either. Megan whispered 
something into Natalie's ear, and Natalie's face darkened. I said "Why 
won't you talk to me? Did I do something wrong?" Megan said "We're not 
friends anymore!" And Natalie said that she wasn't my friend either.
Every morning in kindergarten we sit in a circle on a rug so the teacher 
can do roll call. A couple boys got in a fight that morning, too, and were 
telling the teacher on each other. Things got out of hand and everyone 
started yelling at once, telling about all the bad things anyone has ever 
done to them. I panicked and just shouted "Megan doesn't like me because my 
eyes are small!"
The teacher instantly shushed everyone and pulled me and Megan aside to 
talk to us. She made Megan apologize to me and made us friends again, but I 
never knew if we were actually friends.﻿

People have bullied me since 3rd grade and now I am in middle school they

comments.author: Elise Bustos

comments.text:
When I was a kid, around 5-11 years old, I was bullied. I remember that I 
was very awkward and honestly, I have to say myself that I wasn't exactly 
the cutest looking little girl. I wore baggy jeans, glasses, never brushed 
my hair or teeth, my smile was crooked, and I rarely showered or bathed 
unless my mother made me. Three years later, I'm still bullied, but 
actually because I'm questioning. (I'm not sure if I'm bisexual or a 
lesbian.) I am doing a lot better socially now, however, than I was at a 
young age. I shower daily, brush my teeth, wear better clothing, brush my 
hair, shave, and all of that. I still wear glasses but I think I'm okay 
with them. I'm also a little bit chunky, 5'3 and 140 pounds, but I still 
know I'm cute. Honestly, the best advice I can give to any little girls who 
are being bullied is to take care of yourself and don't let them get to 
you. Smile and wear your skin proudly because it is the only skin you'll 
ever have. -Nikki ♥﻿

comments.author: sweetcake2121

comments.text:
I've never been openly bullied before because I have always either been 
homeschooled or going to the part-time christian school I'm at now but I 
still have been hurt by people. I have been stabbed in the back by people 
who I thought were my friends and I've even been flat out ignored by the 
ones I wish would accept me but I would say that I am my own biggest bully. 
I'm the one who comments on my thighs and hips. I'm the one who points out 
every pimple on my face. I try to change it but it's not as easy as people 
think.﻿
comments.author: AllieK

comments.text:
I'm 13 and eastern European, and my parents have blue eyes, as do I. My 
parents said even when I was a baby I had big blue eyes. A girl in my LA 
class is dyslexic and copies my homework. When I don't let her, she's super 
nice to me just so she can get her grades up. Sometimes I write vague 
answers so when the teacher calls on her she can't explain. Then she gets 
cocky and complains to me about my big blue eyes and my pale skin, and how 
I wear tee shirts all the time. Guess what Annie, tees are super 
comfortable, and I could wear a dress and rock my flat belly if I wanted 
to. And my eyes are beautiful, my complexion just the same. Honestly she 
does this to everyone, I think she's just insecure about herself.﻿
comments.author: Paulina Mostek
